content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2018". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as Administrator, Commissioner, Northern border, and relevant committees of Congress. The Act defines key terms such as Administrator, Commissioner, Northern border, and relevant committees of Congress. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security, and the term "Southern border" denotes the international border between the United States and Mexico. SEC. 3. U.S. CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION PERSONNEL. The Secretary of U.S. Customs and Border Protection is authorized to hire 5,000 full-time officers and 350 support staff by September 30, 2023, for all land ports of entry on the Northern and Southern borders. The Secretary may waive fte limitation to carry out Homeland Security duties. Reports to Congress include plans for outbound inspections and ensuring sufficient personnel at Southern border land ports of entry. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress outlining plans to ensure an adequate presence of relevant personnel at all Southern border land ports of entry, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection agriculture specialists, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service entomologist identifier specialists, and Food and Drug Administration consumer safety officers. Additionally, an annual implementation report must be submitted to Congress one year after the enactment of the Act and annually thereafter. The Department of Homeland Security must provide Congress with a report detailing the implementation plan for staff enhancements at land ports of entry, including the number of additional personnel assigned, distribution methodology, and required strategic plan and model. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure that U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers have secure communication devices for effective communication between ports of entry and with other law enforcement entities. Additionally, a grant program will be established for the purchase of identification and detection equipment, as well as mobile communication devices. The Commissioner may aid in the enforcement of Federal customs, immigration, and agriculture laws by designing, constructing, and modifying ports of entry infrastructure, including living quarters, technology, equipment, and other structures for law enforcement officers serving on the Southern border. The Commissioner is responsible for improving ports of entry infrastructure, including acquiring land and constructing new ports of entry along the Southern and Northern borders. Priority is given to projects that reduce wait times for commercial and passenger vehicles and pedestrians crossing the border. The Secretary consults with various agencies and stakeholders to determine locations for new ports of entry to improve pedestrian crossing wait times, increase trade efficiency, and enhance safety and security at border facilities. The Secretary consults with agencies and stakeholders to determine new port locations, aiming to minimize adverse impacts on the environment, historic resources, commerce, and community quality of life. This subsection does not create rights or liabilities, affect the Secretary's determinations, or impact consultation requirements under other laws. The Secretary has the authority to acquire leaseholds for real property and construction. The Secretary has the authority to acquire leasehold interest in real property and construct or modify facilities as needed. $1 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2018 through 2023, with $5 million allocated for grants. Unobligated federal funds may be rescinded by the Director of the Office of Management. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget has the authority to determine and identify appropriation accounts for rescission of unobligated federal funds. A report must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary of the Treasury within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget has the authority to determine and identify appropriation accounts for rescission of unobligated federal funds, with exceptions for the Department of Defense, Department of Veterans Affairs, and Department of Homeland Security. SEC. 4. IMPLEMENTATION OF GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE FINDINGS. The Secretary, in consultation with stakeholders, will develop a strategic plan for standardized collection of vehicle wait times at land ports of entry, including ensuring standardized manual wait time practices and making current wait time data available online for public reporting. The Secretary will update the strategic plan to include new practices, tools, and assessments. Additionally, a standardized model for staff allocation at ports of entry will be developed in consultation with stakeholders. The Secretary, in consultation with stakeholders, will allocate U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers based on operational priorities, historical staffing levels, and anticipated traffic flows. New outcome-based performance measures supporting trade facilitation goals will be identified, including the impact of trusted traveler and shipper programs. The Secretary will allocate Customs and Border Protection officers based on priorities and traffic flows. Performance measures will assess the impact of trusted traveler and shipper programs on wait times and referrals to secondary inspection facilities, while also considering trade facilitation goals and benefits to stakeholders. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment, detailing new performance measures and the process for incorporating them into existing measures.
